content: The "Biennial Appropriations Act" is cited as the short title. Section 300 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to revise the timetable for the congressional budget process. The timetable for the congressional budget process includes deadlines for the President to submit the budget, the Congressional Budget Office to submit a report, committees to submit views and estimates, Budget Committees to report a concurrent resolution, Congress to complete action on the resolution, and the House to consider appropriation bills by certain dates. The House Appropriations Committee reports the last appropriation bill to be considered in the House by June 10. Congress completes action on reconciliation legislation by June 15. By June 30, the House completes action on biennial appropriation bills and the defense appropriation bill. Congress completes action on biennial appropriation bills and the defense appropriation bill by August 1. On August 1, Congress completes action on biennial appropriation bills and the defense appropriation bill. The fiscal year begins on October 1. In the case of the first session of Congress following a leap year, with a new President, specific dates will override the usual schedule. The budget process timeline includes key deadlines such as the President submitting the budget by the first Monday in April, the Congressional Budget Office submitting a report by April 15, and Budget Committees reporting a concurrent resolution by May 15. Congress must complete action on the budget resolution by June 1, with specific dates for considering appropriation bills in the House by July 1 and July 20. The House completes action on biennial appropriation bills and the defense appropriation bill by July 20. Congress completes action on these bills, the defense appropriation bill, and reconciliation legislation by August 1. The fiscal year begins on October 1. In odd-numbered years, Congress enacts an annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for Financial Services, Transportation, Housing and Urban Development, Interior, Environment, Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Military Construction, Veterans Affairs. In even-numbered years, Congress follows the budget process to consider these bills. In even-numbered years, Congress enacts an annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for Agriculture, Commerce, Justice, Science, Energy and Water, Homeland Security, Legislative Branch, and State-Foreign Operations. Amendments to the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 include changes to the budget process. Amendments to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 define the term 'biennium' as a 2-year period starting on October 1. Changes are made to committee allocations for appropriations for each fiscal year in the biennium and the first fiscal year of the resolution for defense. Amendments to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 include changes to committee allocations for appropriations for defense and each fiscal year in the biennium. This involves adjusting the timeframe from "for that period of fiscal years" to "for all fiscal years covered by the resolution" and specifying allocations for defense and the biennium in subsections (b) and (f)(2)(A). Amendments to Title 31, United States Code are being made. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code include defining 'biennium' and adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for each fiscal year in the biennium and the following four fiscal years. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code involve adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for each fiscal year in the biennium and the following four fiscal years. This includes changes to receipts, balance statements, functions, activities, and allowances. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code involve adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for each fiscal year in the biennium and the following four fiscal years, including changes to receipts, balance statements, functions, activities, and allowances. This includes amendments to various sections of Title 31, such as allowances, uncontrolled expenditures, tax expenditures, and future years. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code involve adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for each fiscal year in the biennium and the following four fiscal years. This includes changes to receipts, balance statements, functions, activities, allowances, uncontrolled expenditures, and tax expenditures. Amendments also address future years by modifying sections related to fiscal years and bienniums. The United States Code is amended to update budget contents and submission to Congress for the two most recent completed fiscal years. This includes adjustments to receipts, balance statements, functions, activities, allowances, uncontrolled expenditures, and tax expenditures. The United States Code is amended to update budget contents and submission to Congress for the two most recent completed fiscal years, including adjustments to receipts, balance statements, functions, activities, allowances, uncontrolled expenditures, and tax expenditures. Amendments include changes to estimated expenditures of the Legislative and Judicial Branches, and recommendations to meet estimated deficiencies in each fiscal year in the biennium. The United States Code is amended to update budget contents and submission to Congress for the two most recent completed fiscal years, including adjustments to receipts, balance statements, functions, activities, allowances, uncontrolled expenditures, and tax expenditures. Amendments include changes to estimated expenditures of the Legislative and Judicial Branches, and recommendations to meet estimated deficiencies in each fiscal year in the biennium. Changes are made to the Capital Investment Analysis section of title 31, United States Code. SEC. 5. Two-year appropriations; title and style of appropriations acts. Section 105 of title 1, United States Code, is amended to specify the title and style of appropriations Acts for nondefense and defense purposes. Nondefense Acts will have a specific format for the title, while defense Acts will have a different format. All Acts making regular appropriations for the Government must include specified amounts. The Act specifies appropriations for defense for the fiscal year, with defined amounts for each year. Definitions for terms like 'biennium' are provided, and technical amendments are made to the table of sections in the United States Code. SEC. 6. MULTIYEAR AUTHORIZATIONS. Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include authorizations of appropriations. Sec. 316 prohibits considering bills authorizing appropriations for less than 2 fiscal years unless no further appropriations are needed. It also restricts authorization or revenue bills until Congress completes budget resolution and appropriations bills. In the Senate, exceptions apply to defense and privileged measures. The Senate has exceptions to considering bills under section 300(b), including defense, privileged measures, matters in Executive Session, and appropriations or reconciliation bills. SEC. 7. CONGRESSIONAL OVERSIGHT requires joint oversight hearings by relevant committees on agency activities not funded under certain conditions. The hearing reviews agency mission, impact of biennial budgeting, cost savings, new programs, and terminated programs. SEC. 8. REPORT ON TWO-YEAR FISCAL PERIOD is also mandated. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must report on the feasibility of a 2-year fiscal period with a biennial budget process within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Act and its amendments will take effect on January 1, 2016, applying to budget resolutions and appropriations starting from fiscal year 2017.
